In determining the order in which the three treatises now before us appeared, we were partly guided by internal marks, and must not therefore now assume the order, and thence draw positive conclusions. But we may go so far as to point out how well the proposed order falls in with the known history of Ter- tullian, and the probable course by which such a person would pass over to such a sect as that of Montanus; and it may not be irrelevant to remark, that the very choice of his subjects is suggestive of some such progress. He first denounces the shows, where he seems to have reason and authority evidently on his side, then trades and pro- fessione and customs, where there is room for doubt ; and lastly, an usage which though undoubtedly mixed up with idolatry, was in itself harmless and indifferent.

1 do not, however, propose to dwell minutely upon the indications of Montanism or of a Montanistic tendency in the several treatises. Some of them will be brought forward in the course of the following remarks upon some of the special arguments employed by Tertullian on the subjects here taken in hand.
